awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is on revolutionizing the real-time Structural Health Monitoring (the entire concrete or other composites where smart cement is use as the binder becomes a 3D sensor and there are no buried sensors) and also pre-warning of infrastructure, building and pipeline failures, fire hazard and seismic activity. This will reduce the loss of life, accidents and disruption of economic activity by enhancing quality control and monitoring throughout the lifetime of the structures. The real-time monitoring will also help maintain the critical structures in a cost effective manner. Smart cement technology can also be used in quality control of mixing concrete with various types of additives and also the curing of the concrete under various environments and also predicting the long-term properties and strength of concrete and other materials where smart cement is used as the binder. The smart cement technology can be used with any type of cement and has a very wide application in civil infrastructures and also oil and gas industry for cementing wells. Also smart cement blocks can be used in old structures and residential buildings for monitoring which will also become a very popular commercial market for smart cement applications.

This I-Corps project will commercialize the Smart Cement which has been recently developed and proven to be a highly sensing and sensitive material to changes in stresses, temperature, cracks contamination, aging and degradation. The smart cement is technically known as chemo-thermo-piezoresistive cement and behavior models have been developed to predict the behavior of the smart cement. The monitoring parameter is the change in electrical resistivity of the material in any direction. This technology can be easily adopted in any type of cement, which is the largest manufactured material in the world annually. Since less than 0.1% of additive (no nano particles) is used in the cement, it is a very cost effective modification and making the cement to be very sensing without changing any other properties and also complies with all the environmental requirements.  When this smart cement is used to make the concrete (cement + aggregate) or binders in other composites (example cement mortar and cement bricks) it will make the material to be very sensing in 3 dimension (3D) and pick changes in any direction. The sensing characteristics can be used from the time of mixing to the entire service life of the structures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
PROJECT OUTCOME REPORT


            Smart Cement Technology uses the newly developed highly sensing chemo-thermo-piezoresistive smart cement (similar to human skin) with the real-time monitoring system (similar to the human brain), a paradigm shift in developing and integrating various fundamental material and monitoring theories and technologies. Cement is the largest human manufactured material in world and it is used in multiple applications onshore and offshore. In making the highly sensing smart cement, regular cement is modified with less than 0.1% additive (no nanoparticles) based on a newly developed material theory and it is a very cost effective modification. Smart cement is over 1000 times (100,000%) more sensitive than the current compressive strain-related monitoring technology that uses strain gages, sensors and fiber optics. Smart cement can be used as the binder in the concrete to make it highly sensing and for health monitoring to determine the changes in the concrete due to all types of loading (static dynamic, earthquakes), changes in temperatures, cracking, gas leaks and contaminations. In addition, a new monitoring parameter has been developed so that it can be easily adopted in the field. Both laboratory and field studies have clearly identified electrical resistivity to be the most sensitive concrete material parameter. 

            The NSF-I Corp program provided the resources and opportunities to discuss not only the new technology with over 350 General Contractors (GC), Concrete Suppliers (CS), Construction Materials Testing (CMT) engineers and owners of major facilities across the United States but also how to integrate the new technology under different construction and maintenance environments. The meetings and discussions with various entities also helped with the development of the business model to commercialize the Smart Cement Technology.

            With the real-time non-destructive monitoring, it will enhance the quality control of the concrete from the time of mixing to the entire service life of the infrastructures enhancing the safety and reduce the cost of operations and maintenance. Methods have been developed to predict the long-term strength of the concrete based on the monitoring properties in one day which will minimize the construction delays currently encountered in the field. This will also reduce the construction cost by up to 5%. The broader impact is on revolutionizing the Structural Health Monitoring (the entire concrete becomes a 3D (3-dimensional) sensor and there are no buried sensors) and pre-warning of infrastructure failure and seismic activity will reduce the disruption of economic activities by enhancing the quality control and monitoring throughout the lifetime of the structure. The monitoring will help maintain the critical structures. Smart cement technology can be used in quality control of mixing concrete and the curing of the concrete under various environments. The technology can be used for monitoring long-term performance of concrete and help with the maintenance. Real-time non-destructive monitoring of the performance of the concrete structures during the service life will reduce the maintenance cost by up to 15% and can improve the safety related issues.

            Lessons learned from this project include various methods of communications with the General Contractors (GC), Concrete suppliers (CS), Construction Material Testing (CMT) engineers and owners to introduce the new technology to be adopted with the current practices and identify the potential partners to transfer the technology and commercialize the product. In addition, potential GC, CS, CMT and owners have been identified to commercialize and implement the Smart Cement Technology. 

 


Last Modified: 04/05/2019
Modified by: Cumaraswamy Vipulanandan
